natural problem: How many positive whole numbers have cube roots that are less than $10$? For example, $20$ would count since $\sqrt[3]{20}<10.$
natural solution: The cube root of 1000 is 10; the cube root of any number smaller than 1000 is less than 10.
So, the whole numbers from 1 to 999 are the only positive whole numbers with cube roots less than 10. There are $\boxed{999}$ such numbers.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<le> 999 \<longrightarrow> n powr (1/3) < 10"
shows  "card {n. n \<in> {1..999} \<and> n powr (1/3) < 10} = 999"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many positive whole numbers have cube roots that are less than $10$? For example, $20$ would count since $\sqrt[3]{20}<10.$ The final Answer is 999
 ### Proof
 The cube root of 1000 is 10; the cube root of any number smaller than 1000 is less than 10.
 So, the whole numbers from 1 to 999 are the only positive whole numbers with cube roots less than 10. There are $\boxed{999}$ such numbers.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<le> 999 \<longrightarrow> n powr (1/3) < 10"
shows  "card {n. n \<in> {1..999} \<and> n powr (1/3) < 10} = 999"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: How many natural numbers from 1 to 999 have a cube root less than 10? The final answer is 999.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. x \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> x \<le> 999 \<longrightarrow> (x powr (1/3) < 10)"
shows  "card {x. x \<ge> 0 \<and> x \<le> 999 \<and> (x powr (1/3) < 10)} = 999"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many positive whole numbers have cube roots that are less than $10$? For example, $20$ would count since $\sqrt[3]{20}<10.$ The final Answer is 999
 ### Proof
 The cube root of 1000 is 10; the cube root of any number smaller than 1000 is less than 10.
 So, the whole numbers from 1 to 999 are the only positive whole numbers with cube roots less than 10. There are $\boxed{999}$ such numbers.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. x \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> x \<le> 999 \<longrightarrow> (x powr (1/3) < 10)"
shows  "card {x. x \<ge> 0 \<and> x \<le> 999 \<and> (x powr (1/3) < 10)} = 999"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: How many numbers from 0 to 999 inclusive have a cube root that is less than 10? The final answer is 999.

fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n > 0 \<longrightarrow> n powr (1/3) < 10"
shows  "card {n. n powr (1/3) < 10 \<and> n > 0} = 999"

 proof-

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<le> 999"
shows  "\<exists>x. x \<ge> 0 \<and> x < 10 \<and> x = n powr (1/3)"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many positive whole numbers have cube roots that are less than $10$? For example, $20$ would count since $\sqrt[3]{20}<10.$ The final Answer is 999
 ### Proof
 The cube root of 1000 is 10; the cube root of any number smaller than 1000 is less than 10.
 So, the whole numbers from 1 to 999 are the only positive whole numbers with cube roots less than 10. There are $\boxed{999}$ such numbers.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat
assumes h0 : "n \<le> 999"
shows  "\<exists>x. x \<ge> 0 \<and> x < 10 \<and> x = n powr (1/3)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find a number $x$ between 0 and 10 (inclusive) such that $x$ is the cube root of a natural number $n$, where $n$ is less than or equal to 999.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and cube_root :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. cube_root n = n powr (1/3)"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. (cube_root n < 10) = (n \<le> 999)"
shows  "card {n. n \<in> {1..999} \<and> cube_root n < 10} = 999"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many positive whole numbers have cube roots that are less than $10$? For example, $20$ would count since $\sqrt[3]{20}<10.$ The final Answer is 999
 ### Proof
 The cube root of 1000 is 10; the cube root of any number smaller than 1000 is less than 10.
 So, the whole numbers from 1 to 999 are the only positive whole numbers with cube roots less than 10. There are $\boxed{999}$ such numbers.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and cube_root :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. cube_root n = n powr (1/3)"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. (cube_root n < 10) = (n \<le> 999)"
shows  "card {n. n \<in> {1..999} \<and> cube_root n < 10} = 999"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: How many natural numbers $n$ between $1$ and $999$ have a cube root less than $10$? The final answer is $999$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: nat
assumes h0 : "x > 0"
and h1 : "root 3 x < 10"
shows  "x \<le> 999"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many positive whole numbers have cube roots that are less than $10$? For example, $20$ would count since $\sqrt[3]{20}<10.$ The final Answer is 999
 ### Proof
 The cube root of 1000 is 10; the cube root of any number smaller than 1000 is less than 10.
 So, the whole numbers from 1 to 999 are the only positive whole numbers with cube roots less than 10. There are $\boxed{999}$ such numbers.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: nat
assumes h0 : "x > 0"
and h1 : "root 3 x < 10"
shows  "x \<le> 999"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: If $x$ is a positive natural number such that the cube root of $x$ is less than 10, show that $x \leq 999$.

a_7.informal problem: How many positive integers $n$ are there such that the cube root of $n$ is less than 10? The final answer is 999.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cube_root :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. cube_root x = x powr (1 / 3)"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. x > 0 \<and> cube_root x < 10 \<longrightarrow> x \<in> {1..999}"
shows  "card {x. x > 0 \<and> cube_root x < 10} = 999"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many positive whole numbers have cube roots that are less than $10$? For example, $20$ would count since $\sqrt[3]{20}<10.$ The final Answer is 999

 *)

fixes cube_root :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"

shows  "card {x. x > 0 \<and> cube_root x < 10} = 999"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: How many positive integers have a cube root less than 10? The final answer is 999.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: nat and cbrt :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. cbrt x = x powr (1/3)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. cbrt x < 10 \<longrightarrow> x \<ge> 1"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. cbrt x < 10 \<longrightarrow> x \<le> 999"
shows  "card {x. x \<in> {1..999} \<and> cbrt x < 10} = 999"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many positive whole numbers have cube roots that are less than $10$? For example, $20$ would count since $\sqrt[3]{20}<10.$ The final Answer is 999
 ### Proof
 The cube root of 1000 is 10; the cube root of any number smaller than 1000 is less than 10.
 So, the whole numbers from 1 to 999 are the only positive whole numbers with cube roots less than 10. There are $\boxed{999}$ such numbers.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: nat and cbrt :: "nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. cbrt x = x powr (1/3)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. cbrt x < 10 \<longrightarrow> x \<ge> 1"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. cbrt x < 10 \<longrightarrow> x \<le> 999"
shows  "card {x. x \<in> {1..999} \<and> cbrt x < 10} = 999"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: How many natural numbers from 1 to 999 have a cube root less than 10? The final answer is 999.
